newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentina's high court allows pension indexation.
newsitem.headline: Argentina's high court allows pension indexation.

text.p: Argentina's supreme court on Friday ruled that the government must increase back payments to 70,000 pensioners by almost 14 percent.
"The court has re-established the mobility of pension payments since they were fixed through Convertibility," Julio Nazareno, the president of the supreme court, said on local television.
Argentina's Convertibility plan, introduced in 1991, pegged the peso at par with the dollar and discontinued the practice of indexing pension payments to changes in the cost of living.
"The pension payments in the 1991 to 1994 period will be adjusted," said Nazareno.

Although it was not immediately clear how much the government will have to pay or how quickly it would have to make back payments, local newspapers have estimated that a 14 percent adjustment would amount to about $3.5 billion.
Some local media have said the back payments may take the form of government bonds.
The pensioners were asking for a 60 percent rise.
The ruling could pave the way for other retired workers in Argentina to make claims against the government for adjustments in their fixed pension payments.
